about.formula_en:
To be classified as BRUE, all of the following must be true:

  • Infant <1 year old.
  • Asymptomatic on presentation (no URI symptoms, no fever).
  • No explanation for the event after conducting history and physical (e.g. GER, feeding difficulties).
  • History of sudden, brief, and now resolved episode consisting of ≥1 of the following:
    • Cyanosis or pallor.
    • Absent, decreased, or irregular breathing.
    • Marked change in tone (hyper or hypotonia).
    • Altered level of responsiveness.

The risk of serious underlying condition and the risk of recurrent event are calculated based on the following inputs:

  • Age, days
  • History of similar event*
  • History of multiple events or event clusters*
  • Abnormal medical history*
  • Prematurity (<32 weeks or between 32–38 weeks and corrected to <45 weeks)*
  • Absent, decreased, or irregular breathing*
  • Marked change in tone (hyper or hypotonia)*

*Yes = 1, No = 0

% risk of serious underlying condition = [ex/(1 + ex)]*100

where x = -3.7545 + 0.00252*(Age, days) + 0.5644*(History of similar event) + 0.6457*(Abnormal medical history)

% risk of recurrent event = [ew/(1 + ew)]*100

where w = -2.4355 + 0.5844*(History of similar event) + 1.172*(History of multiple events or event clusters) + 0.4637*(Prematurity) + 0.3622*(Cyanosis or pallor) - 0.3187*(Absent, decreased, or irregular breathing) - 0.3038*(Marked change in tone)

Original/Primary Reference.text: Nama N, Hall M, Neuman M, et al. Risk Prediction for Underlying Diagnosis and Recurrence of Brief Resolved Unexplained Events Hospital Pediatrics. 2022.

Other References.text: Tieder JS, Sullivan E, Stephans A, et al. Risk factors and outcomes after a brief resolved unexplained event: a multicenter study. Pediatrics. 2021;148(1):e2020036095.
Merritt JL, Quinonez RA, Bonkowsky JL, et al. A framework for evaluation of the higher-risk infant after a brief resolved unexplained event. Pediatrics. 2019;144(2):e20184101.
Tieder JS. Mortality risk and hospital admission after a brief resolved unexplained event. J Pediatr. 2018;197:12-13.
Tieder JS, Bonkowsky JL, Etzel RA, et al. Brief resolved unexplained events (Formerly apparent life-threatening events) and evaluation of lower-risk infants. Pediatrics. 2016;137(5):e20160590.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use the Brief Resolved Unexplained Events 2.0 (BRUE 2.0) Criteria for Infants and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en:
• Provide education around BRUE and reassurance (https://doi.org/10.1542/ppe_document103).

  • Engage in shared decision-making with the families if testing and hospital admission is a consideration using the above calculated risks. This decision needs to be guided by the family’s values, the patient’s risk, worrisome features on history or exam, and access to close follow-up.

  • Provider caregivers with resources on CPR training.

  • Consider a brief period of monitoring for 1-4 hours to obtain serial evaluations of the infant, as well as monitor for event recurrence.

  • Involve a social worker (or a trained provider) to perform a psychosocial assessment, screen for child abuse and provide caregiver support.

  • Feeding evaluation by a trained provider.

  • Consider the need for diagnostic testing (rapid viral panel, and pertussis in high-risk groups).

  • Further consultations and diagnostic testing should be tailored to findings on history and physical examination.

  • Ensure adequate follow-up to evaluate and manage any persistent symptoms.

calc.full_title_en: Brief Resolved Unexplained Events 2.0 (BRUE 2.0) Criteria for Infants

input_schema.subheading_instructions: Must fulfill all 4 to evaluate for BRUE 2.0

input_schema.name: asymptomatic
input_schema.tips_en: E.g. no <abbr title='Upper respiratory infection'>URI</abbr> symptoms, no fever

input_schema.label_en: No explanation for the event after conducting history and physical
input_schema.name: explanation

input_schema.subheading_instructions: History of sudden, brief, and now resolved episode consisting of ≥1 of the following:

input_schema.conditionality: infant_year==1 && asymptomatic==1 && explanation==1 && (cyanosis ==1 || absent ==1 || marked ==1 || altered ==1)
input_schema.name: age

input_schema.conditionality: infant_year==1 && asymptomatic==1 && explanation==1 && (cyanosis ==1 || absent ==1 || marked ==1 || altered ==1)
input_schema.name: similar

input_schema.conditionality: infant_year==1 && asymptomatic==1 && explanation==1 && (cyanosis ==1 || absent ==1 || marked ==1 || altered ==1)
input_schema.label_en: History of multiple events or event clusters
input_schema.name: multiple

input_schema.conditionality: infant_year==1 && asymptomatic==1 && explanation==1 && (cyanosis ==1 || absent ==1 || marked ==1 || altered ==1)
input_schema.name: history

input_schema.conditionality: infant_year==1 && asymptomatic==1 && explanation==1 && (cyanosis ==1 || absent ==1 || marked ==1 || altered ==1)
input_schema.label_en: Prematurity (<32 weeks or between 32–38 weeks and corrected to <45 weeks)
input_schema.name: premature

calc.instructions_en: Use in infants <1 year old who are asymptomatic and in their normal state of health at the time of evaluation. Do not use in symptomatic patients (e.g. fever, respiratory distress) or those with obvious cause for prior symptoms.
calc.medium_description_en: Classifies unexplained events, improves on the BRUE Criteria.

creators.about_en: Joel S. Tieder, MD, MPH is a Professor of Pediatrics in the Division of Hospital Medicine at Seattle Children’s Hospital and the University Of Washington School Of Medicine. He is a pediatric hospitalist with scholarly focus on improving the delivery of quality care for hospitalized children, particularly through overcoming healthcare disparities and the use of evidence-based and family-centered care. Nationally, he is the Chair for the American Academy of Pediatrics’ Council for Quality Improvement and Patient Safety.
creators.name: Dr. Joel S. Tieder

creators.about_en: Nassr Nama, MD, MSc, FRCPC, FAAP is a Clinical Assistant Professor of Pediatrics in the Division of General Pediatrics at British Columbia Children’s Hospital and the University of British Columbia. He is a pediatric hospitalist with research interests focused on improving care for hospitalized children, particularly by expediting evidence synthesis and providing risk stratification tools that allow physicians to safely allocate precious clinical resources to high-risk patients.
creators.name: Dr. Nassr Nama

creators.about_en: Matt Hall, PhD is a principal biostatistician affiliated with the Children’s Hospital Association (CHA) and the Director of their Health Services Research Academy and Children’s Hospitals Institute of Pediatric Research (CHIPR)SM. He provides statistical support to all CHA divisions with a particular focus on health services and policy research. His statistical interests lie in multi-level modeling, nonparametric statistics, and graphical representations of large datasets. He has co-authored over 300 papers in peer-reviewed medical journals and is on the editorial board for Hospital Pediatrics. He is an ex officio board member of Pediatric Research in Inpatient Settings (PRIS) and is the research mentor for faculty members in the Division of Hospital Medicine at Children’s Mercy Hospital in Kansas City, MO.
creators.name: Dr. Matt Hall

cme_faq.answer: MDCalc’s Continuing Medical Education (CME) service allows users to easily earn AMA PRA Category 1 CreditsTM through regular use of MDCalc. Simply put, on top of getting the best medical calculators in the world, your usage will help you achieve your annual CME requirements, including specialty CME, without any extra effort.
cme_faq.question: What is MDCalc CME?

cme_faq.answer: Yes, in support of improving patient care, this activity has been planned and implemented by the Postgraduate Institute for Medicine and MDCalc Ltd. Inc. Postgraduate Institute for Medicine is jointly accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE), and the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), to provide continuing education for the healthcare team.
cme_faq.question: Is MDCalc CME accredited?

cme_faq.answer: Only United States attending physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and physician assistants are eligible for our CME service.
cme_faq.question: Who can enroll and how?

cme_faq.answer: We have over 275 CME-eligible calculators across various specialties. You can read the clinical content supporting any CME calculators to start earning. Once you have viewed all the supporting content for a calculator, you will have officially earned the credit amount (0.5 credits) and will be able to redeem a certificate. For now, only calc content in CME-eligible calcs is eligible for CME credits, however, we’ll be expanding our CME service to include more of our content in the future.
cme_faq.question: What activities can I do to earn CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: Simply use our search bar or visit our homepage to easily find CME-eligible calcs. You must be enrolled in our CME service to see which calcs are CME-eligible.
cme_faq.question: Where can I find calcs with which I can earn credits?

cme_faq.answer: Once you’ve enrolled in our CME service, you will have a personal CME Dashboard where you can view all of your earned credits. You can navigate to the dashboard by clicking the CME button in the header at the top of any page.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see which credits I’ve earned?

cme_faq.answer: Go to your CME Dashboard and select the credits you’d like to redeem, fill out a few dropdown answers about how you used the calc, and then proceed to checkout.
cme_faq.question: How do I redeem CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: No. Earning credits as you use calcs is free, but either you (or your employer) will need to purchase an annual subscription to redeem your CME certificates.
cme_faq.question: Are CME credits free?

cme_faq.answer: Just like with earned credits, you can view your CME certificates on your CME Dashboard in the “CME Certificates” tab. Certificates include a list of all of the calcs for which CME was earned along with a tally of the specialty CME.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see my CME certificates?

cme_faq.answer: One year from the date of purchase.
cme_faq.question: How long do credits in an annual subscription last?

cme_faq.answer: General; Addiction and Controlled Substances; Cardiac Care; Domestic and Intimate Partner Violence; Geriatrics; HIV and Infectious Disease; Hospice, End-of-Life, Terminal Illness, and Palliative Care; Mental and Behavioral Health; Pain Management; Pediatrics; Stroke; and Trauma.
cme_faq.question: What specialty CME credits are included in the plan?

cme_faq.answer:
Your gift card will be sent via email within 1-2 business days of making your purchase. You will be able to select from the following options - Visa, Amazon.com, Apple. Be sure to claim your gift card offer within 90 days of receiving the email.

Your CME purchase may have implications for tax reporting purposes. The cost of your CME product may or may not be tax-deductible when used for professional purposes. Any reimbursed amount for incentives must be declared as personal income for tax purposes. Please consult your tax advisor. MDCalc does not provide tax advice.
cme_faq.question: I ordered a CME package with a gift card. How does it work?

cme_faq.answer: Per the new guidelines from ACCME, the receipt will separate the cost you paid into the cost of the gift card and the cost of the CME learning activity.
cme_faq.question: What will show on my receipt for CME when it includes a gift card?

cme_faq.answer: You can get a refund (minus any promotional gift amount) within 30-days if the ease of earning and redeeming does not meet your expectations and if you have redeemed no more than 4 credits. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request a refund.
cme_faq.question: How do I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

cme_faq.answer: You can upgrade your subscription throughout your billing cycle and pay the difference for a higher plan. You may request to downgrade your plan to a lower level to coincide with your next renewal. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request changes.
cme_faq.question: How do I later upgrade to a different plan if I need more credits?

cme_faq.answer: Gift card plans are available for 1 year and do not auto-renew. Standard, non gift-card subscriptions are auto-renewed annually. You can disable the automatic renewal of your subscription at any time by emailing team@mdcalc.com.
cme_faq.question: Do CME plans auto-renew?

cme_faq.answer: If you’re part of a team or practice that wants to sign up five or more physicians, please email us at team@mdcalc.com for more information.
cme_faq.question: How do I get information on a discounted bulk subscription program for my institution, team, or practice?

cme_faq.answer: On July 28, 2022, ACCME updated the guidelines regarding the use of high-value incentives. These guidelines allow for the use of gift card rewards in a regulated manner. Visit the ACCME website to read their guidelines.
cme_faq.question: Did the ACCME decide to regulate gift cards?
